headline: Renee's Strawberry Rhubarb Pie
description: This strawberry rhubarb pie bakes for an hour and uses strawberries, rhubarb and cinnamon for a winning combo.
name: Renee's Strawberry Rhubarb Pie
recipeIngredient: 1 recipe pastry for a 9 inch double crust pie
1 tablespoon turbinado sugar (such as Sugar in the Raw®)

recipeInstructions.text: In a bowl, whisk together the cornstarch with 1 tablespoon of water until thoroughly combined. Stir in the rhubarb, strawberries, white sugar, lemon juice, cinnamon, and vanilla extract. Allow the mixture to stand for 30 minutes.
Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). Place bottom crust into a 9-inch pie dish. Roll the remaining crust out into a 10-inch circle on a floured work surface, and set aside.

Stir the filling, and pour into the prepared pie dish. Cut the remaining crust into 1-inch wide strips (use a scalloped edge pastry cutter for a prettier crust). Moisten the rim of the filled bottom crust with a bit of water, and lay the two longest strips in a cross in the middle of the pie. Working from the next longest down to the shortest strips, alternate horizontal and vertical strips, weaving the strips as you go. Press the lattice strips down onto the bottom crust edge to seal, and trim the top crust strips neatly. Beat the egg white with 1 teaspoon of water in a small bowl, and brush the entire lattice top with the beaten egg white. Sprinkle with turbinado sugar. Wrap aluminum foil strips around the edges of the pie.

Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes; reduce heat to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C), and bake until the crust is browned and the filling is bubbling, 40 to 45 more minutes. Remove the aluminum foil for the last 10 minutes of baking time. Allow pie to cool completely before serving.

review.reviewBody: Just as I suspected, 2 Tablespoons is not enough thickening agent. It was a strawberry rhubarb soup, not pie. I'd follow this recipe again but probably use more like 1/4-1/3 cup corn starch. I think as long as it is dissolved in some liquid beforehand it will dissolve fine and the taste will be gone. I would have cooked it longer to let it thicken up and let the liquid evaporate out a bit, but the crust was getting such a burned look on it I decided soup for dessert it is!
YES, Great Recipe! I Added 1/8 teaspoon Salt To Fruit. Old Habit To Bring Out Sweet And Tartness of Fruit
turned out delicious but so runny it no longer looked like a slice of pie. had to eat with a spoon.
Awesome recipe!! Turned out wonderfully and my family insisted I make it again!

Other than adding a 1/4 cup of maple syrup and after letting the mixure sit for 30 minutes I strain the juice into a pot. Boil the juice until thickened. Let cool for about 15 minutes. Add back to the rhubarb strawberries before placing into the pie shells. Makes a less juicy pie. We love this recipe. My wife and I just made 11 pies for friends and family.
It was great as is.
Delicious! Wonderful pie!
I have been looking for a strawberry rhubarb pie recipe for many years. This is now my absolute favorite. I did cut the cinnamon in 1/2. It came out perfect. I would give it 10 stars if i could.

Love how the flavor turned out! I decided to use up all the strawberry and rhubarb I had, so it ended up being about 4 cups each of fruit. It fits because it cooks down, but I knew the juice would overflow (which it did) so I placed the pie on a baking sheet to contain juice. I adjusted the other ingredients accordingly. Lastly, for those wondering like me, do you really need the foil on the outside crust? If you want an even color, then yes. Although I don't mind, because my crust, while dark, still tasted good.
I made this last night. It does not have enough cornstarch. It needs another 2 TBS of cornstarch at least. I had a nicely flavored rhubarb soup, but it definitely wasn't the finish I was going for.
Very good
Quick, easy and delicious!
Touch less cinamon.....but thank you Renee!
No real changes...other than home made crust. Used cookie cutters to create big stars instead of lattice...for 4th of July. Turned out beautiful.

Great taste. This is more of a fall-season pie, with all the cinnamon (could reduce and not lose flavor). Two full crusts would also be too much crust/filling ratio as was lattice top. Fruit compacts, so I will add more fruit next time, too.
Delicious, I didn't change anything
Best I’ve ever made.

I cut sugar back to 1 cup, omitted the cinnamon, and added 1/2 tsp of ground ginger. Because I only had 1/2 cups of rhubarb after dicing, I added an extra cup of sliced strawberries. The flavor was a little tart and exactly what I was looking for. I might not leave the mixture to sit next time, since the fruit had extra time to lose juice this way.

Love this pie! I reduced the cinnamon a bit and used my own favorite pie crust so I can’t comment on this particular crust. This is a very juicy pie - after the filling sits for 30 minutes - stir to combine well and then make sure the pie sits extra time after baking to solidify a bit. I have made so many of these pies this season and also freezes well to savor it past strawberry season!

I followed the recipe to the letter and the end result was wonderful. I really like that there wasn't too much sugar. Love the tartness. The next time I will add some flour to the filling to tighten it up a bit. 

This one is a keeper.

I loved this recipe!!! t was perfect, I changed 1 1/4 cups of sugar to 1 cup honey and 1/4 of a cup sugar, I also did not put the egg whites on the crust, and I used 1 1/2 cups of strawberry's, because I didn't have enough. This was still amazing, and I loved it!!! And it was all eaten up, before I could have seconds!!

The pie is runny even if you use a lattice top. My recommendation is to use a 1/4 cup of instant tapioca instead of the cornstarch and water. I also only use a 3/4 cup of white sugar for a more tart flavor.
I added additional corn starch as even though my rhubarb was frozen and drained, it was way too runny. I put in about 4T of cornstarch.
OMG, thank you for sharing love this
I used a crumbled crust for the top crust and it worked great.

I doubled the recipe. I was short 1 cup of rhubarb and substituted some fresh black cherries (I pitted) that I had. I cut back the sugar to 2 cups instead of 2 1/2 cups. I tripled the cornstarch/water mixture and I still had trouble with some soupiness (which I drained real quick before putting in pies.). This had very good flavor and the black cherries didn’t interfere with this great tasting pie. Oops, almost forgot— I added 1/4 tsp. of nutmeg. BTW, make sure you put a piece of parchment paper between your pie and the cookie sheet you place it on in the oven. It’ll save you some clean-up, my dears.

This is my go-to strawberry rhubarb pie recipe! My Grandmother used to make it for me when I was young and it has always been my favorite. She passed away a few years ago from Alzheimer’s and due to the disease I was never able to get her recipe from her. This recipe nails it on how I remember hers tasting! I follow the recipe exact and never have any issues with it being “soupy”. I do let it cool completely and then refrigerate it till ready to eat. If you’re not in the mood for pie, make the filling as specified in the recipe and heat it up on the stove to desired thickness. After it cools, spoon over vanilla ice cream!
This recipe has made my family so happy! Rhubarb and strawberries from my garden, transformed into the best pie ever!!!! I made three this week! Thanks Renee!!!
This recipe has made my family so happy! Rhubarb and strawberries from my garden, transformed into the best pie ever!!!! I made three this week! Thanks Renee!!!

Turned out a lot better than I expected! Everyone enjoyed it! Made a double recipe (risky for a first trial!) with locally grown strawberries (slightly thawed from frozen and sliced) and rhubarb from my garden. I did add the cinnamon and vanilla, but also added 1.5 Tbsp flour per recipe to the fruit mixture. I used commercial pie shells that I half baked and lined with toasted bread crumbs before filling with the fruit mixture. I opted to just top the pie with a crisp topping. Otherwise, I followed the recipe’s directions. The pie tasted fruity and light, not too sweet or runny. I think the cinnamon and vanilla gave depth to the flavour of this pie. I would definitely make this again, and it’s a tasty way to use up my rhubarb!
I hadn't had a strawberry rhubarb pie since I was a kid. Fastforward 30 years and believe it or not it tastes just like Mom used to make
Two tablespoons of corn starch wasn't enough. Although the pie tasted good, it was watery.
I reduced sugar to 1 cup. Removed cinnamon & vanilla extract. Tastes great
I reduced sugar to 1 cup. Removed cinnamon & vanilla extract. Tastes great

I increased the cornstarch from 2 to 3 tbsp and added 2 tbsp of flour, as well as 1/4 tsp of nutmeg. I also doubled the water and vanilla and reduced the sugar to 1 cup. I think it was still too sweet, next time I'll use 1/2 cup of sugar. I used a 10 in glass pan instead of the recommended 9 in and didn't have any spillover while baking. I let it sit for about 6 hours to cool completely before cutting and it kept its shape.

Very good, not runny at all. Used 3 cups of each fruit, omitted cinnamon and vanilla. While fruit was sitting in cornstarch/sugar I had it in a colander. A lot of liquid drained but so did sugar. It was a little tart so when serving we added a dollop of sweet Dandelion Jelly...excellent!
I added blueberries.
This was the first time making my favorite pie! I used butter instead of shortening and the results were amazing! This will be my go to recipe for future bakes!
Everyone LOVED this pie! Definitely will make again.

Easy, delicious, and even my sweets-averse wife loves it!
The vanilla and cinnamon seemed strange additions, but they worked perfectly with the strawberries and the rhubarb.
Superb!
I added 3 tbls corn starch and used a solid top crust that had small vents cut in it. It turned out delicious and not watery. I used 1 1/4 cups sugar and no sugar on top crust.
I have made this as a pie and as a crumble and as a fruit compote with whipped cream and it is always great and delicious. I’ve even used frozen rhubarb. Still great!!
It was SO delicious and it was my first homemade pie, but was easy to make.
Will definitely make again! Great balance of sweet and tart. The only thing I did was add a bit of nutmeg along with the cinnamon and used a homemade all butter crust.
Awesome. Made it several times and it is wonderful...always turns out.
Reduced the sugar by half, I don't like pies sugary sweet. Family loved it, will make again!!!
Fantastic!
Made this last night, i too added extra corn starch and a 2T flour. It turned out perfect, husband loved it.

Great recipe! I added a little more lemon because I like the tartness; maybe doing so made the filling a little more runny, but it was super good! Easy recipe to follow; I didn't blind bake the crust and it turned out fine.

I LOVE LOVE this recipe!!! I have shared it many times over. I do add more cornstarch as it gets a bit runny for my tastes. the first time I did not add the cinnamon as it did not sound good to me...the second time I did add it and it made all the difference in the world!! Brought out all the flavors!!!

Recipe is easy to follow, and comes with a good result. I wish I took another reviewer's recommendation to reduce the amount of sugar, as I am a fan of tartness. The insides are still delicious, so if you prefer a more sweet version you are fine.

I also replaced the special sugar with light brown sugar, a similarly acting ingredient. The resulting crust looked very brown, unless that was from the position in the oven.

All in all, good piece, and would make again!
Never had this pie before so I tried a piece and loved it. Found two recipes on this site I like this one the best.
Delicious recipe! Made it fresh and had the perfect level of sweetness and bitter!!

I have made this pie a few times and it is AMAZING. I never get leftovers when I take this to any event. Use some extra creamy whipped cream or make your own and add vanilla and cinnamon and you have a combo where you could finish half a pie by yourself. I 100% recommend this pie and share this recipe with everyone.

Delicious! I cut back on the sugar to only 1 cup but we like our rhubarb tart. I also left out the cinnamon as I don't care for it. Still, it was yummy and the proportion of rhubarb to strawberries was perfect.
Made it just as recipe called for. It's in the cooling stage so haven't taste-tested yet. Makes a beautiful picture :-)

I followed the directions to a T and the pie turned out with way too much liquid which I had to remove from the pie. I questioned the small amount of corn starch, but went ahead with the amounts listed in the recipe. A rule of thumb (according to chef John) 1 table spoon of corn starch per cup of fruit. In this case 5 table spoons of corn starch would have been better

This was the best Strawberry Rhubarb revipe ive ever made. I let the fruit set up for several hours before baking because i didnt have time to bake and didnt want to heat house up but i could tell it was not going to disappoint. I will make again but with a different crust recipe than the one i found.
Definitely will make again. It was slightly runny, but it was because I didn’t have the desired amount of Rhubarb. Had it for dinner a la mode and for breakfast the next day! Yum!

BEST PIE EVER!
As others suggested I used 1C sugar. I used 3T corn starch and mixed it in with the sugar mixture. Omitting the water.
I’ve got a lot of rhubarb & strawberries in my freezer! Can’t wait to make this again!

Homemade crust. Ruth’s Grandmas pie crust. Substitute butter for shortening. Makes a lot but freezes well.

My husband absolutely loves the flavor of this pie, I want to thank you for that. I have made it twice, both times the pie has been very runny. I believe next time I will try the thickening that I use for my raspberry pie.
Flavor was great. I would add more cornstarch next time, as this was still runny after cooling for several hours. I used more rhubarb than strawberries.

My pie stuck to the bottom of the pie dish. It was a royal little mess getting it out and onto plates, and then nobody had great things to say about it except a couple tepid "it's good" comments. To be fair, I served this to real rhubarb pie aficionados, but I can't help but be disappointed.
A little less cinnamon,really nice.
Good recipe!
It was awesome, and yes, I will definitely make it again.
reduced the amount of sugar
Absolutely delicious!
The pie is great nice flavor and sweetness BUT who started putting crunchy sugar on top of a crust?
In order for the pie not to be soupy, you'll need at least 1/4 to 1/3 cup cornstarch. Two Tablespoons is way too little. Rhubarb gives off lots of liquid.

This pie turned out delicious, but I was very nervous that I would make yet another soupy rhubarb pie after reading the reviews. I decided to try a few of the other reviewers' suggestions. I increased the corn starch to 1/4 cup, sprinkled tapioca on the bottom crust plus substituted a little less than 1/4 cup of strawberry jello for 1/4 cup of the sugar. It may have been overkill, but I can't stand runny, soggy rhubarb pie! Next time, I will probably eliminate the egg white wash because the crust turned brown too quickly.

I made it last night, and used a different pie crust receipt. I wish I pre-baked the pie shell. Was not sure about pouring everything into pie shell, so I just scooped in the fruit. With the top crust being one piece, I cooked the pie 25 min longer, it came out great!!

First time making a pie other than Apple, followed the directions to a T and was told that it was too runny and was too sweet. Tried a piece next day to see for myself and agreed. The rest of the pie is just going to waste
Followed the recipe exactly as I have no experience with rhubarb. This pie is amazing!!
This made a great pie, I didn't do the lattice top crust, too much work to watch it get consumed.
Loved it. Thank you for the recipe. I can't wait to make it every year now.
I really adored the beautiful pie that this made, but it was too sweet for us. Next time I will add less sugar!
everyone luv it
Made 2.......one for my neighbor. They haven"t stopped raving about it! I mistakenly doubled the vanilla, but I think that made it even yummier!

I've made a lot of strawberry rhubarb pies, as it was my husband's favorite and a favorite of all 3 of my sons. This recipe got a BIG thumbs up from everyone including my grandbabies who usually don't like pie! I didn't change a thing. I used my own crust recipe.

This pie was delicious. I gave it a 4 only because I left out the cinnamon and vanilla. Otherwise followed exactly. Measurements were perfect, cook time was perfect. Some others pre-cook rhubarb - all the way back to my great grandmother we have never done that so I don't either. The cornstarch thickens it enough so it's not too juicy and as long as you cut your rhubarb about 1/2 inch thick you should be fine. This will be my go to recipe from now on.
love the taste but I end up having too much liquid ,it didn't thicken
Being a type 2 diabetic I used Truvia Baking Blend instead of sugar and it still turned out fantastic,

I made this pie this morning and it turned out delicious. 
I used frozen berries and rhubarb so I added one more tbspoon of corn starch. I didn't add any lemon or cinnamon. 
After I was done baking, I let the pie cool down for 2hours. I think I should have left it for one more hour, cuz it was still warm and with the first slice some juice came out of it. 
Overall it wasn't soggy or anything. I am very happy with the results.
I followed the recipe and it turned out great!
This may have been the best pie I have ever had! Thanks for a great recipe, The only change I made was to add one tablespoon of flour. I'm not a fan of a runny pie. It was perfect1

would've been perfect except a bit too sweet, cut back sugar
by 1/2 c and cut cinnamon in half...is zippy and fresh-tasting.
don't use rhubarb that is (even a little) woody - cooking doesn't
fix stringiness. also be sure to let pie sit in (turned off) oven
after baking for 1/2 hr to ensure filling won't have "floury" flavor
This is delicious! I took the advice of some of the other readers, cutting the sugar back to 1 cup and adding 3T of instant tapioca. Perfect. I will definitely make this again.

Made this tonight for a work function on Thursday. I haven't been able to try it yet, but I made it exactly to the recipe and it smells amazing! Made it early because I want to allow time for it to set, based on the info I got from other reviews. Only downfall, my lattice work is subpar at best, so I wish it had been prettier.
Easy recipe with great flavour! It was a little juicy the first day, but firmed up the next. We liked it!
double the cornstarch leave out the vanilla and this pie is the bomb.
My 15 year old son made this for the family and it was absolutely delicious!
nice and easy to follow and it turned out great!
After reading the other comments, I used three tablespoons of cornstarch, cut back sugar to 1 cup and added 1/4 tsp of nutmeg. Just the right amount of sweet and tart. Great recipe!
I been looking for the one so i am going to use this recipe i gald that i found this think

What a marvellous pie! Using a sprinkling of turbinado sugar created an interesting texture on the lattice crust. We added some lemon zest and juice to our taste, but I would recommend this receipt to anyone. Using the lattice top crust maximized evaporation of excess juices and placing the pie low in the oven ensured a flakey bottom crust. Five good sized stalks of rhubarb makes a full 9" pie.
This was excellent. I didn't make any changes!
Simple and delicious! Mine only took 30 minutes to bake
This was great!! I took the advice of a reviewer and used 1/4 teaspoon of nutmeg instead of the cinnamon. Other than that, I made the pie as written and loved it!
